docs.lead_paragraph: Audibility, at least, is not a problem in the Roundabout Theater Company's production of ''Arms and the Man.'' The actors' voices, though congested with mossy English accents, boom, shriek and bellow even in calmer moments, giving the Gramercy Theater a decibel level to match that of Irving Plaza, the nearby rock arena. Somewhere along the way, it seems, a decision was made to take the words ''screamingly funny'' to heart. The overall impression to emerge from this high-strung revival, which opened last night under Roger Rees's direction, is that George Bernard Shaw must have written his satire of martial glory and romantic heroes entirely in capital letters. Mr. Rees, a first-rate British actor who has been directing more and more with varied results, here sustains an air of artificial urgency that emphasizes the play's farcical aspects without being very funny.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1971 film ''La Mortadella,'' Sophia Loren played a feisty would-be immigrant who is arrested by United States Customs officials in New York for refusing to surrender a 20-pound mortadella, the traditional pork sausage of Bologna. A cult classic in Italy, the satire was aimed at what the director, Mario Monicelli, called the ''authoritarian rigidity'' of American society. After an outbreak of African swine fever in Italy in 1967, Italian pork products were banned in the United States for decades. Mortadella, however, has finally been freed. The United States Department of Agriculture announced in the Federal Register last month that as of today, it would lift certain restrictions on bringing pork and pork products into the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: Somewhere between a boiled wool skirt and a divine silk rumba dress, two anti-fur protesters briefly interrupted Oscar de la Renta's fall fashion show yesterday in the main tent in Bryant Park. The women were tackled by security guards, dragged to an exit and detained by the police as the models resumed their sultry progress down a white runway left stained with black scuff marks. Perhaps because the tactics of anti-fur demonstrators are so familiar to people in the fashion world, the ruckus stirred little more than mild interest. Mr. de la Renta said afterward that he had watched the whole thing on a video monitor backstage. He didn't seem fazed. A few fur-clad clients joked among themselves that maybe they ought to seek cover in the second row. But otherwise the disturbance produced the same world-weary reaction of boredom that fashion people reserve for looking at clothes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Michele Savoia's Time Has Come For 16 years Michele Savoia has been sewing custom-made suits for men in the manner of those worn during the 1940's. For just as many years, most of his adult life in fact, he has longed for a return to midcentury civility. ''You see people out at night in T-shirts that say things on them,'' he lamented from his East Village studio and shop. ''They were out all day in those T-shirts, and that's what you're sitting next to in a restaurant. It's unfair.''

Life isn't easy for Sean Combs, music mogul and aspiring fashion star. But he's persevering. ''I'm going to put on an incredible show, put out an incredible record,'' he said in the Manhattan offices of his clothing label, Sean John, a few days before his first fashion show, which took place at the Bryant Park tents on Saturday night. docs.lead_paragraph: It is one measure of the dizzy uncertainty of this year's Oscar race that one of the handful of sure bets for a nomination goes to a screenwriter, Alan Ball, who came from television to write the dark and acidly funny ''American Beauty.'' He seems more likely than most to hear his name read at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at the hideous crack of dawn on the morning after Valentine's Day. ''It's a little overwhelming, actually,'' Mr. Ball said. ''There's a certain amount of stress involved. I never expected this movie to get made, much less get made by a major studio and much less be at the center of Oscar speculation.''

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 12, Elliot Magaziner won a violin competition that had as its prize a chance to play at the Westchester County Center. By the time he was 19, he was touring the world with the American Ballet Theater. And in World War II, he was part of the Army Air Corps entertainment unit, working with Charlton Heston, Donald O'Connor and Red Buttons. Mr. Magaziner's career started early and is still going strong. A resident of Eastchester who also lived for many years in White Plains and for almost 30 years did live television as part of the CBS Orchestra -- during which time he played with Frank Sinatra, the Beatles and some of the world's most famous classical musicians -- Mr. Magaziner, 78, now teaches and conducts the orchestra at Manhattanville College in Purchase. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with him.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Crime of Sheila McGough By Janet Malcolm. Vintage, $12. A rigorously intelligent journalist chronicles the drama of a disbarred lawyer who claims she was framed but may have been the victim of her own relentless honesty, blinkered loyalty and poor storytelling skills. ''No other writer tells better stories about the perpetual, the unwinnable, battle between narrative and truth,'' Margaret Talbot wrote here in 1999. Empress of the Splendid Season By Oscar Hijuelos. HarperPerennial, $13. Lydia Espana, the heroine of this tender novel by the author of ''The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,'' is a romantic Cuban emigre who is forced by the death of her prosperous husband to become a cleaning lady for wealthy Manhattanites. As she navigates between two alien worlds, she struggles to reconcile her instinct for self-invention with her inability to invent a suitable self. ''The New York that emerges in this novel is as layered as Lydia's inner life, as infused with meaning,'' Verlyn Klinkenborg wrote in these pages last year. ''The city both echoes and shapes her moods.'' Brazilian Adventure By Peter Fleming. Northwestern University, $16.95. In this Pythonesque 1933 travelogue, Fleming (a literary editor and brother of Ian) recounts his voyage with a bunch of squabbling Brits in search of a missing explorer deep in the Brazilian jungle. His acerbic account of their ''hilarious safari'' is ''full of rich, rare and entertaining reading,'' C. G. Poore wrote here. Sonny Liston Was a Friend of Mine: Stories By Thom Jones. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $12.95. The author's third collection of short fiction features his usual gallery of lost souls and hard-luck cases, many of whom are given to esoteric drug use because the world has failed them. Each story is ''a raw, adrenalinized chunk of conflicted emotion and barely suppressed rage,'' Dwight Garner said here last year. Kaddish By Leon Wieseltier. Vintage, $15. The author's journal of the year in which he formally mourned his father is also a deeply personal meditation on rabbinical tradition and the relevance of sacred Judaic texts to his own life. The result ''is an astonishing fusion of learning and psychic intensity,'' Harold Bloom wrote in these pages in 1998. TraveLing Mercies: Some Thoughts on Faith, by Anne Lamott (Anchor, $13), is a collection of exuberant essays tracking the author's rocky search for spiritual faith. ''Lamott is a narrator who has relished and soaked up the details of her existence, equally of mirth and devastation . . . and spilled them onto her pages,'' Alexandra Hall said here last year. The Scapegoat By Daphne du Maurier. University of Pennsylvania, $15.95. An unhappy British teacher meets his physical double in a French bar, is drugged and wakes up to find that the stranger has exchanged clothing and documents, leaving him little choice but to slip into another identity. Big mistake: it turns out his alter ego had plenty to escape. In 1957 our reviewer, Anthony Boucher, called this a ''magnificent thriller.'' The same publisher has reissued The House on the Strand ($15.95), in which a rootless former editor becomes addicted to a potion that allows him to commute between contemporary and 14th-century Cornwall. His own life soon pales in comparison with the medieval drama. The result is ''prime du Maurier,'' David Dempsey wrote here in 1969. ''Her skill in finessing the time shifts is enough to make one want to try a little of the brew himself.'' Fredy Neptune: A Novel in Verse By Les Murray. Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14. This verse novel, which unfolds in relaxed eight-line stanzas, is about an Australian sailor who loses the ability to feel pain and drifts through the horrors of the 20th century. The result is ''a haunting, loving, fiercely democratic epic by a master poet,'' Ruth Padel said in these pages last year. ''You Ain't Heard Nothin' Yet.'' The American Talking Film: History & Memory, 1927-1949 By Andrew Sarris. Oxford University, $18.95. This free-form collection of notes and essays by a seasoned film critic known for his missionary zeal is less a history than a personal tour of the images he encountered on the screen. ''The prose is full of bounce and opinion . . . and plenty of finely flung allusions,'' Michael Wood wrote here in 1998. All on Fire: William Lloyd Garrison and the Abolition of Slavery By Henry Mayer. St. Martin's Griffin, $18.95. This dramatic biography seeks to re-establish the Boston abolitionist newspaper editor as a major figure in 19th-century history who wielded the power of a biblical prophet. ''Much of the narrative is fluently and fascinatingly rendered,'' Carla Davidson wrote here in 1998. ''Mayer has an especially strong sense of place.'' The Sandglass By Romesh Gunesekera. Riverhead, $12.95. This densely plotted tale focuses on two warring families in Sri Lanka whose rift echoes the often-violent divide between the country's Sinhalese and Tamil peoples. Last year our reviewer, Jacqueline Carey, called it ''an important novel.'' Scott Veale
